DOC.HEADLINE: CONEXANT BUYS SOFTWARE DESIGNER MAKER COMMUNICATIONS

TEXT.P: Maker Communications Inc. which develops software that enables engineers to create semiconductors essential to Internet communications, has agreed to be acquired by Conexant Systems Inc. for $942.8 million in stock.

Under the agreement, Conexant, of Newport Beach, Calif., will pay $43.76 per Maker share, based on Conexant's closing price Monday of $66 5/16. That works out to 0.66 shares of Conexant for each Maker share.
The price is 28 percent higher than the Maker's 34 1/4 closing price on Friday, the date both companies used in calculating the value of the stock deal.
Maker's stock soared 7 1/2 points to close at 41 3/4. Conexant shares dropped 3 5/16.

Maker, which went public in May, is little known outside the semiconductor industry and is one of the few New England chip-design software firms. Maker's software enables engineers to create devices that process and switch data, voice and video in communications networks.

The five-year-old Framingham, Mass. company's software is used in communications systems, including switches and network access products. The company's software enables customers to develop high-speed, programmable, custom-designed chips for these and devices that can help speed up the flow and delivery of information on the Internet.

For Conexant, which was spun off from Rockwell International Corp. a year ago to focus on developing communications devices, the pending acquisition of Maker is ``a strategic bullseye,'' said Dwight W. Decker, Conexant's chairman and chief executive.

In a teleconference, William N. Giudice, Maker president and chief executive, said no layoffs are planned, adding that company plans to expand employment in Massachusetts from 80 people to 130 by the end of next year. Giudice will stay on as head of Framingham operations.
Maker will be part of Conexant's network access division. The Maker software will be marketed by Conexant's 250-person sales force.
``With Conexant we can grow faster,'' said Giudice.
Both Conexant and Maker produce chips and software for customers such as as Cisco Systems Inc. and Nortel Networks Corp.

Indeed, Maker's incoming owners have ambitous plans for the small software company. Decker said he expects to expand Maker's business to reach annualized revenue of about $100 million by the end of 2001.
That's a sizable gain. Maker earned $830,000 on revenues of $4.1 milliun in the third quarter. Net income for the first nine months of 1999 was $1.3 million on sales of $10.8 million.
Conexant, whose sales doubled to $277.9 million in fiscal 1999 which ended in September, said the Maker deal will reduce its profit by as much as one cent a share in fiscal 2000.
